title: Analyzing and Improving Speaker Similarity Assessment for Speech Synthesis
author: Marc-Andre Carbonneau (Ubisoft La Forge), Benjamin van Niekerk (Stellenbosch University), Hugo Seute (Ubisoft La Forge), Jean-Philippe Letendre (Ubisoft La Forge), Herman Kamper (Stellenbosch University), Julian Zaïdi (Ubisoft La Forge), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses automatic speaker verification embeddings and proposes a new metric for rhythm which aligns closely with Haohe Liu's research interests in audio generation and synthesis, focusing on capturing speaker identity.
background: The study investigates how speaker identity is assessed in generative speech systems, emphasizing the limitations of current speaker verification methods when applied to synthesis.
contribution: This paper introduces the U3D metric to solve the problem of neglecting dynamic aspects of speaker identity in existing embeddings, achieving better assessment of rhythmic patterns in speech.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focus on static features like pitch and timbre in automatic speaker verification embeddings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by implementing U3D to specifically quantify dynamic rhythm patterns, enriching the assessment of speaker similarities.

key_innovation: U3D models rhythm using duration distributions from phonetic content, allowing for a deeper analysis of speaker identity in speech synthesis without the need for phonetic annotations.
real_world_impact: Improving speaker similarity assessments in voice synthesis can enhance the quality of virtual conversations and applications in entertainment, thereby making synthesized voices more realistic and relatable.
limitations: No limitations are explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.dynamic rhythm patterns: This refers to the variations in rhythm during speech that reflect individual identity, contrasting with static features like pitch or timbre.
new_terms.U3D (Unit Duration Distribution Distance: A new metric proposed in the paper for measuring rhythmic characteristics in speech, focusing on duration distributions of phoneme-like groups.

open_sourcing: The code implementing U3D and the prescribed best practices is publicly available.
